discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Monitor Mode has open access even before and after authentication.
Low impact mode has open access before but is controlled by an ACL until the device authenticates to have a new ACL applied.
Closed denies all non-eap traffic until authentication is successful.

comments.content:
correct answer is C
The key here is: Which ISE deployment mode restricts all traffic initially (Close mode).
Initially, monitor and low-impact mode do not restrict all traffic

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
IEEE 802.1x Deployment Modes -> High-Security Mode (Closed)
- NO access for unauthorized supplicants.

Selected Answer: C
C. closed mode

Here's why closed mode is the correct choice:

 Closed Mode: In this mode, the switch port initially restricts all traffic (except EAP and potentially DHCP and CDP/LLDP) until the client successfully completes 802.1X authentication.
 After successful authentication, access control rules defined in Cisco ISE are applied based on policies configured in the authorization profile.
 If 802.1X authentication fails, the port can be configured to grant limited access or no access at all, depending on the specific configuration.

https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/ise-secure-wired-access-prescriptive-deployment-guide/ta-p/3641515

comments.content: Low-Impact doesn't deny all traffic. It allows PXE traffic for example

questions.question_text: A client connects to a network and the authenticator device learns the MAC address 04:49:23:86:34:AB of this client. After the MAC address is learned, the 802.1 x authentication process begins on this port. Which ISE deployment mode restricts all traffic initially, applies a rule for access control if 802.1x authentication is successful, and can be configured to grant only limited access if 802.1 x authentication is unsuccessful?

choices.D: The policies are merged, but dynamically downloaded policies receive priority.
choices.A: Dynamically downloaded policies override local policies in all cases.
choices.B: Local policies override dynamically downloaded policies in all cases.
choices.C: The policies are merged, but local policies receive priority.

questions.question_text: An organization has a SGACL locally configured on a switch port, but when a user in the Executives group connects to the network, they receive a different level of network access than expected. When Cisco ISE pushes SGACLs to the switch after the authorization phase, how does the switch decide which access to grant the user?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Only conflicting policies are overridden.

comments.content: A is stating in "all cases" but the document states any conflicting policies which means it will not affect any existing local policies that are not conflicting.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
An SGACL policy downloaded dynamically from the Cisco Secure ACS or a Cisco ISE will override any conflicting locally-defined policy.
https://content.cisco.com/chapter.sjs?uri=%2Fsearchable%2Fchapter%2Fcontent%2Fen%2Fus%2Ftd%2Fdocs%2Fswitches%2Flan%2Fcatalyst9500%2Fsoftware%2Frelease%2F16-11%2Fconfiguration_guide%2Fcts%2Fb_1611_cts_9500_cg%2Fm9-1611-trustsec-sgacl-policies.html.xml&platform=Cisco%20Catalyst%209500%20Series%20Switches&release=IOS%20XE%20Gibraltar%2016.11.x#concept_wrg_5pl_2gb

D:
An SGACL policy downloaded dynamically from the Cisco Secure ACS or a Cisco ISE will override any conflicting locally-defined policy.

Selected Answer: AB
No such thing as a "Coa Policy" in ISE.

comments.content: sorry CoA is none, change to reauth

questions.question_text: An administrator is configuring endpoint profiling and needs to enable CoA for devices that change profiles. Which two actions must be taken to accomplish this goal? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Ensure that the firewall is not blocking port 1700
choices.E: Enable the CoA policy and create rules for each type
choices.D: Modify the RADIUS endpoint attribute filters to send CoA actions as the profiles change
choices.B: Define "reauth" in the default CoA action to be used
choices.C: Use an API to detect when profile changes occur and send instructions to ISE to provide a CoA

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Sounds most likely like firewall blocking access, 8443 is the port for portal

Selected Answer: B
Answer should be B (or D). Guest portal is using port 443 and not 8443 which is used for admin portal. Therefore, A and C are wrong.

A:
Since default port for portal is 8443.

questions.question_text: A Cisco ISE administrator is setting up Central Web Authentication to be used for user endpoint authentication. The client cannot reach the guest portal to log in and gain access, but DNS is functioning properly and the guest portal is enabled. What else must be configured to gain access?

choices.C: Configure the guest portal to listen on TCP/8443.
choices.A: Allow port TCP/8443 on the firewall.
choices.D: Allow redirection from any client IP range.

discussion.content:
D & E
Join Point Name 
Active Directory Domain

You are required to specify Active Directory Domain name, when you join active directory join point.

choices.E: Add an Active Directory Join Point.
